instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Had bad liquid damage .
Put through the US and came out nice and clean. but No power, no lights at all on charger,

using known good DC board and flex and Original charger, 

Nothing in SMC- Bypass mode.  
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  0.0V doesn't come high. 
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 16.95
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0v

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
1) 0.00
2) 16.74
3) 0.00
9) 0.00
12) 0.105
13) 0.105
14) 0
15) 0
17) 0
19) 5.051v
20) 5.051v
27) 0

Bit stuck now, Should I be checking around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"3) 0.00
..............
12) 0.105"
Missing ACIN and <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Fis these first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Any pointers for a starting point dude?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> was giving me 16.95v on pin 1 and 0.047 on pin 2, I can see that pin 2 should be 4.3v so I replaced <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> from a donor board same result, 16.95 on pin 1 and 0.047 on pin 2 so presume something else is causing this?

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> readings
1)  1.267
2)  3.422
3)  7.250
4)  3.425
6)  16.73
8)  16.74

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I meant to check <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> voltages, not its ohm value.
Diode mode to ground at ACIN pins?
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR> and check again; if good, replace <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR>.
If still bad, change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

"12) 0.105
..............
2)  3.422"
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Those <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> readings was voltages not ohm.
<CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR> was bad! replaced that still had the same problem, Replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and ping, I get green orange light on charger and now getting 3.848v on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>

But still no fan spin and wont start in <SIGNAL>SMC_BYPASS</SIGNAL> where to go now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Post exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
